item.title: Beginner’s Guide to Event Kit in Swift – Requesting Permission
item.description: Updated on October 26, 2016 – Swift 3.0 EventKit provides a set of classes for accessing and manipulating a user’s calendar events and reminders. In the tutorial that follows, my goal is to walk you through the first steps of setting up an app that utilizes EventKit. I will demonstrate how to request permission to the user’s calendar and show a couple of examples for how to handle the user’s response (for when they grant access, or deny it).

item.title: Fundamentals of NSNotificationCenter in Swift
item.description: Updated on September 19, 2016 – Xcode 8 & Swift 3.0 The goal of this post is to help you grasp the fundamentals of using NSNotificationCenter in your Swift iOS app. The topic isn’t necessarily new, and there’s no difference except syntax between Objective-C and Swift implementations involving NSNotificationCenter. item.title: Create Sound Clips from iTunes
item.description: Open iTunes. (optional) Import any songs you’d like to make clips for. Select (click) the song that you’d like a sound clip for so that it’s the only one selected. Right-click that song and select “Get Info”. A window will appear – Click “Options” to access the screen to set your start and stop times. Check the boxes next to “Start Time” and “Stop Time”. Enter a start time in the text box next to “Start Time”.
